title.children: ASX drops ahead of RBA interest rate decision, Wall Street mixed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB is predicting that the Reserve Bank will keep interest rates on hold at 4.10 per cent at tomorrow's board meeting, but says the central bank will hike rates in November to 4.35 per cent. NAB says although the Monthly CPI Indicator (5.2 per cent) did show sticky services inflation, it thinks the RBA is likely to wait for confirmation in the full Q3 CPI on October 25. NAB also says the risk of a prolonged high inflation "is being realised given poor productivity and  services inflation being sticky, even before potential impacts from the lower AUD and from higher oil prices".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NAB sees the RBA hiking rates in November

children.content: NAB is predicting that the Reserve Bank will keep interest rates on hold at 4.10 per cent at tomorrow's board meeting, but says the central bank will hike rates in November to 4.35 per cent.
NAB says although the Monthly CPI Indicator (5.2 per cent) did show sticky services inflation, it thinks the RBA is likely to wait for confirmation in the full Q3 CPI on October 25.

NAB also says the risk of a prolonged high inflation "is being realised given poor productivity and  services inflation being sticky, even before potential impacts from the lower AUD and from higher oil prices".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas pilots in Western Australia will stop work for 24 hours on Wednesday amid wage negotiations. It means more than 50 flights, including Qantaslink routes from Perth to regional WA towns such as Exmouth, Karratha, Geraldton and Kalgoorlie, as well as to mine sites, will be affected. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) says the union has to take industrial action because pilots who work at Network Aviation are paid "significantly lower than pilots at comparable airlines". "The AFAP remains committed to reaching an agreement for our members in Western Australia who fly for Qantas subsidiary Network Aviation and is disappointed that we have had to take this action," senior industrial officer Chris Aikens says. The AFAP represents more than 85 per cent of the commercial pilots employed by Network Aviation to fly passenger transport (PT), and fly-in, fly-out (FIFO) and private charter aircraft in Western Australia. This pilot group is negotiating a new enterprise agreement to replace the Network Aviation Pilots Enterprise Agreement 2016, which expired on Oct 31, 2020. Network Aviation operates passenger services on aircraft with the QantasLink tail in WA.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas pilots in WA to strike over pay dispute

children.content: Qantas pilots in Western Australia will stop work for 24 hours on Wednesday amid wage negotiations.
It means more than 50 flights, including Qantaslink routes from Perth to regional WA towns such as Exmouth, Karratha, Geraldton and Kalgoorlie, as well as to mine sites, will be affected.

The Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) says the union has to take industrial action because pilots who work at Network Aviation are paid "significantly lower than pilots at comparable airlines".

"The AFAP remains committed to reaching an agreement for our members in Western Australia who fly for Qantas subsidiary Network Aviation and is disappointed that we have had to take this action," senior industrial officer Chris Aikens says.

The AFAP represents more than 85 per cent of the commercial pilots employed by Network Aviation to fly passenger transport (PT), and fly-in, fly-out (FIFO) and private charter aircraft in Western Australia.
This pilot group is negotiating a new enterprise agreement to replace the Network Aviation Pilots Enterprise Agreement 2016, which expired on Oct 31, 2020.
Network Aviation operates passenger services on aircraft with the QantasLink tail in WA.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares were flat after midday, while cautious investors awaited the key interest rate decision by the Reserve Bank on Tuesday. The RBA is scheduled to give out its interest rate decision, with expectations that it will hold its key interest rate steady at 4.10 per cent on Tuesday but hike it to a peak of 4.35 per cent next quarter, a Reuters poll of economists shows. Separately, data in the US on Friday showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August. The Federal Reserve tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target. Back home, financials descended 0.1 per cent with two of the "big four" banks trading in negative territory. A slump in oil prices took energy stocks lower by 0.7 per cent. Sector major Woodside Energy and Santos toppled over 0.1 per cent. On the other hand, gold stocks and technology stocks gained 0.8 per cent and 0.2 per cent, respectively. Export-reliant miners also rose 0.6 per cent, with behemoths BHP and Rio Tinto trading in the positive territory. Among individual stocks, Liontown Resources gained 0.7 per cent after Hancock Prospecting increased its stake to 12.4 per cent in the company.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX flat after midday

children.content: Australian shares were flat after midday, while cautious investors awaited the key interest rate decision by the Reserve Bank on Tuesday.

The RBA is scheduled to give out its interest rate decision, with expectations that it will hold its key interest rate steady at 4.10 per cent on Tuesday but hike it to a peak of 4.35 per cent next quarter, a Reuters poll of economists shows.

Separately, data in the US on Friday showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August. The Federal Reserve tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target.
Back home, financials descended 0.1 per cent with two of the "big four" banks trading in negative territory.
A slump in oil prices took energy stocks lower by 0.7 per cent.
Sector major Woodside Energy and Santos toppled over 0.1 per cent.
On the other hand, gold stocks and technology stocks gained 0.8 per cent and 0.2 per cent, respectively.
Export-reliant miners also rose 0.6 per cent, with behemoths BHP and Rio Tinto trading in the positive territory.
Among individual stocks, Liontown Resources gained 0.7 per cent after Hancock Prospecting increased its stake to 12.4 per cent in the company.
(Reuters)
(Reuters)
